content: I often find myself moving around different topics/streams/PMs while composing a message in a certain narrow without closing the compose box and then want to go back to the narrow I'm composing the message to. It would be nice to have a button(if in a different narrow) near compose box to go back to the topic/pm I'm composing the message to instead of having to click the stream name, and then the topic name(sometimes this could take longer if the topic isn't in the 4-5 topics displayed on clicking stream name)

Yup, it would be nice to always have a button that basically narrows you to the narrow matching the compose fields. This would help the create-new-topic experience for me, and I guess it would also help newbies.

That sounds useful!

I guess the most natural place for this is near the topic/PM addressee, but I kind of want to see how the rest of the changes we're planning on making to the compose box (topic/PM switcher, preview tabs) play out to decide exactly where this button should go.

I'll try opening a PR as we think it'd be useful. Placing it beside topic/recipient input boxes seems like the best option to me but it should be easy to move it around in case we conclude it doesn't work there.

Opened #19590 for this. Placed the button in the top right. (Actually thought of having it right beside the topic input but we'd have to have it placed at different position for pms which might be odd.)

Here's a video of it working: zulip_narrow.gif (Any idea why there's weird flickering with the recording software I'm using? :thinking: )

The icon used is https://fontawesome.com/v4.7/icon/dot-circle-o. I expected it to look something like Github's go-to-issue button.

Also considered https://fontawesome.com/v4.7/icon/bullseye but it looks odd.

Any other ideas?

I really like this approach. The button may not be super discoverable at first, but it's super low cost in terms of real estate, and I think we want to try this feature out first on advanced users, and then work to make it a good newbie experience. (I'm not saying the current implementation is bad for newbies, necessarily; I would be curious how many newbies would figure it out.)
(I don't have strong opinions on the icon itself. I think no matter what icon we pick, folks are gonna have to either hover to see a title tip or learn it socially.)

I think we want to try this feature out first on advanced users

Agreed. We'll have more feedback to improve upon and know if users find it useful.

I think most people would discover it out of curiosity when replying in interleaved views but I agree it might not be easily discoverable at first as it'll be hidden for most of the time.

An alternative UI we could consider is having a popup like the one that happens when you send to a topic you're not narrowed to before you send. That would take some tuning to feel right, I think, but seems much more understandable.
(screenshot)

We'd probably only want to display this when there are messages from outside the narrow visible on the screen (so not in a stream view that just happens to be set up so that all the messages visible are in one topic)

This might help people understand the zulip model better as well, although I really do think that the fundamental way we should fix this category of problem is by making it way harder for people to get into stream narrows (via #18549 or similar)

We should also consider avoiding the need for a button by automatically changing your narrow when you edit the stream you're sending to (and maybe also when you edit the topic?)

That's a somewhat bigger change, but if we change the narrow when focus goes out of the stream/topic box, it would maintain the ability to look at a different topic than the one that you're composing to, while (IMO) likely reducing a lot of confusion.

I interpret that icon on GitHub not as "go to issue", but as "an open issue". There's an icon like that anywhere that an issue is referred to in the UI -- like in the list of issues on a project (at the left of each row), or at the top of an issue page (just below the issue title). It's that circled-dot icon if the issue is open, and a circled checkmark if the issue is closed.

Thanks for the feedback, Wesley Aptekar-Cassels! I agree with your concerns.

One downside of the banner strategy is that it doesn't offer an obvious way to advertise the Ctrl+. keyboard shortcut, which we could readily do with a tooltip if we do an icon. The tooltip text could be something like: "Narrow to compose recipient (Ctrl+.)".

OK, here's a hopefully final version of this detail, which I've pushed to #19590 and will be deploying here shortly:

  • We display a second line in the tooltip when it is potentially confusing. This means (1) the message you're composing would appear in the current view and (2) the current view is a stream narrow, all-private-messages narrow, or all-messages narrow. The last two could be potentially confusing if all the messages on screen are in the conversation in question (E.g. all of your last 20 messages are PMs with a single individual).
  • We do not display a second line in other situations.
  • We avoid displaying the stream name, since that's hard to style, so the messages are, e.g., "Currently viewing the entire stream." or "Currently viewing all private messages."

This avoids all the complexity (and bugs!) with trying to provide descriptions for situations where this button's appearance won't be confusing in the first place, like if you're composing a private message while viewing a search view for messages in public streams containing the word "turtle". Which seems appropriate given that this line is just a refinement to settle folks' feeling of it being confusing that this button appears when they thought they were already looking at the view they're composing to.
